name: app.py
content:
"""
EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App
published on https://eeg100.org

written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk)
in 2024

using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment
"""

from pathlib import Path
import json
import html

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

from module_startpage import (
    server_map, ui_map)
from module_participant import (
    server_participants,ui_participants)
from module_impact import (
    server_impact, ui_impact)
from module_priorities import (
    ui_priority, server_priority)
from module_predictions import (
    ui_prediction, server_prediction)

from shiny import App, Inputs, Outputs, Session, ui

# load data
cwd = Path(__file__).parent
data = pd.read_csv(cwd/"data"/"resp_data.tsv", sep="\t")
data_text = pd.read_csv(cwd/"data"/"text_data.tsv", sep="\t")
with open(cwd/"data"/"desc_data.json","r") as f:
    data_desc = json.load(f)
with open(cwd/"data"/"meta_data.json","r") as f:
    data_meta = json.load(f)

# generate country data
with Path(cwd/"data"/"countries.json").open("r") as f:
    country_dict = json.load(f)
country_dict = {country_dict[i]["name"]:country_dict[i]["code"] for i in range(len(country_dict))}
data_country = pd.DataFrame({"Country":data["Country"],"N":["a"]*len(data)}).groupby("Country").count().reset_index()
data_country["Countrycode"] = data_country["Country"].apply(lambda x: country_dict[x] if x in country_dict.keys() else np.nan)
data['Country'] = data['Country'].fillna('n/a')  # weirdly, cant do this before aggregating data, as 'n/a' breaks the plot

# html escape text responses - to prevent 
for k in data_text.keys():
    data_text[k] = data_text[k].apply(lambda x: html.escape(str(x)))
    # restore ', &, and nan
    data_text[k] = data_text[k].apply(lambda x: str(x).replace(''',"'"))
    data_text[k] = data_text[k].apply(lambda x: str(x).replace("&","&"))
    data_text[k] = data_text[k].replace('nan', np.nan)

# order participant data
order_sex = ["Male","Female","Non-binary / third Gender","Prefer to self-describe", "Prefer not to say"]
data['Gender'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['Gender'], categories=order_sex, ordered=True
).fillna(order_sex[-1])

order_age = ['18-24','25-34','35-44','45-54','55-64','65-74','75 or older','Prefer not to say']
data['Age'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['Age'], categories=order_age, ordered=True
).fillna(order_age[-1])

order_career = [
    'Ph.D. student', 'Completed PhD',
    'Postdoctoral Researcher or Staff Scientist', 
    'Assistant Professor or equivalent', 
    'Associate Professor or equivalent', 
    'Full Professor', 
    'Other', 
    'Prefer not to say']
data['Career Stage'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['Career Stage'], categories=order_career, ordered=True
).fillna(order_career[-1])

order_institution = ['University','Independent Research Institute','Healthcare Organisation','Government Agency','Commercial Entity','Other','Prefer not to say']
data['Organisation'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['Organisation'], categories=order_institution, ordered=True
).fillna(order_institution[-1])

order_handson = ['Yes', 'No']
data['Worked with EEG'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['Worked with EEG'], categories=order_handson, ordered=True)#.fillna(order[-1])

order_papers = ['1-5 publications','6-10 publications','11-20 publications','21-50 publications','More than 50 publications']
data['EEG Papers'] = pd.Categorical(
    data['EEG Papers'], categories=order_papers, ordered=True)#.fillna(order[-1])


# 
keys_notext = [k for k in data_desc.keys() if "_TEXT" not in k]
keys_text = [k for k in data_desc.keys() if "_TEXT" in k]

app_ui = ui.page_navbar(
    ui_map("tab1"),
    ui_participants("tab2", data),
    #test_ui(id="tab3", keys_notext=keys_notext,keys_text=keys_text),
    ui_impact("tab3", data),
    ui_priority("tab4", data),
    ui_prediction("tab5", data),
    header=ui.include_css(Path(__file__).parent / "styles.css"),
    id="tabs",
    title="EEG100 Community Survey",
)


def server(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session):
    server_map(id="tab1", data=data, data_meta=data_meta, data_country=data_country)
    server_participants(id="tab2", data=data, data_meta=data_meta)
    #test_server(id="tab3", data=data, data_desc=data_desc)
    server_impact(id="tab3", data=data, data_desc=data_desc, data_meta=data_meta, data_text=data_text)
    server_priority(id="tab4", data=data, data_desc=data_desc, data_meta=data_meta, data_text=data_text)
    server_prediction(id="tab5", data=data, data_desc=data_desc, data_meta=data_meta, data_text=data_text)
    
    
app = App(app_ui, server)

""" EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App published on https://eeg100.org written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk) in 2024 using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment """ import pandas as pd from shiny import Inputs, Outputs, Session, module, render, ui, reactive import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from matplotlib.colors import to_rgb from seaborn import histplot, move_legend, color_palette from numpy import array, argsort def selection_sidebar(data): return ui.sidebar( #ui.card( # deprecated the groupby option! # ui.card_header("Group By"), # ui.input_select( # "groupby", # "", # choices=['No grouping'] + ['Gender', 'Age', 'Career Stage', 'Organisation', 'Worked with EEG', 'EEG Papers'], # ), #), ui.card( ui.card_header("Subset Data"), ui.input_select( "gender", "Gender", choices=['all']+list(data['Gender'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "age", "Age Group", choices=['all']+list(data['Age'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "career_stage", "Career Stage", choices=['all']+list(data['Career Stage'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "organisation", "Type of Organisation", choices=['all']+list(data['Organisation'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "country", "Country", choices=['all']+sorted(data['Country'].unique()), ), #ui.input_select( # "worked_with", # "Worked with EEG", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['Worked with EEG'].unique()), #), #ui.input_select( # "n_papers", # "Number of EEG Papers", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['EEG Papers'].unique()), #), ui.output_text_verbatim("show_n",placeholder=True), ), #ui.card( # ui.card_header("Metric"), # ui.input_select( # "metric", # "", # choices=['Count', 'Density'], # ), #), width="300px", ) @module.ui def ui_impact(data:pd.DataFrame): return ui.nav_panel( "Past: Impact", ui.page_fluid( ui.layout_sidebar( selection_sidebar(data), ui.card( ui.card_header("Biggest impact of EEG so far"), ui.output_plot("plot_impact"), height="600px" ), ui.card( ui.output_plot("plot_legend"), height="200px" ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Major breakthroughs"), ui.output_ui("text_breakthrough"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Will EEG become redundant?"), ui.output_ui("text_redundance"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ) ) ) @module.server def server_impact(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session, data: pd.DataFrame, data_desc:dict, data_meta:dict,data_text: pd.DataFrame): @reactive.Calc() def filtered_data() -> pd.DataFrame: data_out = data if input.gender() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Gender"] == input.gender()] if input.age() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Age"] == input.age()] if input.organisation() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Organisation"] == input.organisation()] if input.career_stage() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Career Stage"] == input.career_stage()] if input.country() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Country"] == input.country()] return data_out def _textresp(field): desc = data_desc[field]#.upper() desc = "?
".join(desc.split("? ")) # d = list(data_text[field].sample(frac=1)) resp = [] for res in d: if isinstance(res,str): resp.append(res.strip()) #print(res) resp = [r for r in resp if r!=""] # count = ( "
====================" f"
{len(resp)} answers" "
====================" ) return "

".join([desc+count]+resp) @render.text def show_n(): return f"N={len(filtered_data())} of {data_meta['N_used']}" @render.plot def plot_legend(): # define overall order field = 'Most impact so far_' order_all = [data[f"{field}{i}"].apply(pd.to_numeric).mean() for i in range(1,11)] order_all = argsort(order_all)+1 coltitles = [data_desc[f"{field}{k}"] for k in order_all] coltitles = [v.split(' - ')[-1] for v in coltitles] f,ax = plt.subplots() pal = color_palette('dark', n_colors=len(coltitles))[::-1] handles,labels = [],[] for i in range(len(order_all)): handles.append(plt.Rectangle((0, 0), 0, 0, facecolor=array(to_rgb(pal[i])), edgecolor='black')) labels.append(f"{i+1} {coltitles[i]}") ax.legend( handles=handles, labels=labels, #title=field, handlelength=4) move_legend( ax, "center", #bbox_to_anchor=(.5, 1), ncol=2, frameon=False, title="Average rank across all participants" ) plt.axis('off') ax.set_aspect(.1) f.tight_layout() @render.plot def plot_impact(): if len(filtered_data()) < 3: plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot", horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='center') plt.axis('off') else: #field_ = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby() # deprecated groupby option field_ = None keys = list(filtered_data()[field_].cat.categories) if field_ else ['All data'] keys_present = keys if keys == ['All data'] else [k for k in keys if k in filtered_data()[field_].unique()] n_groups = len(keys) if field_ else 1 f,axes = plt.subplots(n_groups) if n_groups==1: axes = [axes] for i,key in enumerate(keys): #axes[i].set_title(key) # deprecated the groupby option! if key not in keys_present: axes[i].text( .5,.5,"no data\nto plot", horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='center') axes[i].axis('off') else: # impact so far field = 'Most impact so far_' # define overall order order_all = [data[f"{field}{i}"].apply(pd.to_numeric).mean() for i in range(1,11)] order_all = argsort(order_all)+1 # corresponds to number of question # define local order #order_local = [filtered_data()[f"{field}{i}"].apply(pd.to_numeric).mean() for i in range(1,11)] #order_local = argsort(order_local)+1 #order_q = [i for i in range(1,9)] + [10,9] #order_q=order_local[::-1] # labels coltitles = [data_desc[f"{field}{i}"] for i in range(1,11)] coltitles = [v.split(' - ')[-1] for v in coltitles] # subset data ks = ['ResponseId'] + [f"{field}{i}" for i in order_all] if field_ is None: data_Q_imp = filtered_data()[ks] else: data_Q_imp = filtered_data()[filtered_data()[field_]==key][ks] data_Q_imp = pd.wide_to_long(data_Q_imp, field, 'ResponseId',"Q").reset_index() x_ticks = [str(i) for i in range(1,11)] x_tick_labels = [o for o in x_ticks] x_tick_labels[0] += '\n(most)' x_tick_labels[-1] += '\n(least)' q_dict = {i+1:t for i,t in enumerate(coltitles)} data_Q_imp['Q'] = data_Q_imp['Q'].apply(lambda x: q_dict[x]) # set global order of items (for consistent colors) data_Q_imp['Q'] = pd.Categorical( data_Q_imp['Q'], categories=[coltitles[i] for i in order_all[::-1]-1], ordered=True)#.fillna(order[-1]) # set order of reponses (1-10) data_Q_imp = data_Q_imp[data_Q_imp[field].notnull()] data_Q_imp[field] = pd.Categorical( [str(int(v)) for v in data_Q_imp[field]], categories=x_ticks, ordered=True)#.fillna(order[-1]) # plot histplot(x=field, data=data_Q_imp, hue='Q', multiple="stack", palette='dark', legend=False, ax=axes[i]) if i == len(keys)-1: axes[i].set_xticks(axes[i].get_xticks(), labels=x_tick_labels) axes[i].set_xlabel("impact ranking") else: axes[i].set_xticks(axes[i].get_xticks(), labels=['']*10) axes[i].set_xlabel("") @render.text def text_breakthrough(): return _textresp('Breakthroughs so far_TEXT') @render.text def text_redundance(): return _textresp('Redundant_TEXT')

name: module_participant.py
content:
"""
EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App
published on https://eeg100.org

written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk)
in 2024

using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment
"""
import pandas as pd
from shiny import Inputs, Outputs, Session, module, render, ui, reactive
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.colors import to_rgb
from seaborn import histplot, move_legend, color_palette
from numpy import array
from numpy.linalg import LinAlgError


def selection_sidebar(data):
    return ui.sidebar(
        ui.card(
            ui.card_header("Group By"),
            ui.input_select(
                "groupby",
                "",
                choices=['No grouping'] + ['Gender', 'Age', 'Career Stage', 'Organisation', 'Worked with EEG', 'EEG Papers'],
            ),
        ),
        ui.card(
            ui.card_header("Subset Data"),
            ui.input_select(
                "gender",
                "Gender",
                choices=['all']+list(data['Gender'].cat.categories),
            ),
            ui.input_select(
                "age",
                "Age Group",
                choices=['all']+list(data['Age'].cat.categories),
            ),
            ui.input_select(
                "career_stage",
                "Career Stage",
                choices=['all']+list(data['Career Stage'].cat.categories),
            ),
            ui.input_select(
                "organisation",
                "Type of Organisation",
                choices=['all']+list(data['Organisation'].cat.categories),
            ),
            ui.input_select(
                "country",
                "Country",
                choices=['all']+sorted(data['Country'].unique()),
            ),
            #ui.input_select(
            #    "worked_with",
            #    "Worked with EEG",
            #    choices=['all']+sorted(data['Worked with EEG'].unique()),
            #),
            #ui.input_select(
            #    "n_papers",
            #    "Number of EEG Papers",
            #    choices=['all']+sorted(data['EEG Papers'].unique()),
            #),
            ui.output_text_verbatim("show_n",placeholder=True),
        ),
        ui.card(
            ui.card_header("Metric"),
            ui.input_select(
                "metric",
                "",
                choices=['Count', 'Density'],
            ),
        ),
        
        width="300px",
    )


@module.ui
def ui_participants(data:pd.DataFrame):
    return ui.nav_panel(
        "Participants",
        ui.page_fluid(
            ui.layout_sidebar(
                selection_sidebar(data),
                ui.layout_columns(
                    ui.card(
                        ui.card_header("Age"),
                        ui.output_plot("plot_age"),
                        ),
                    ui.card(
                        ui.card_header("Gender"),
                        ui.output_plot("plot_gender"),
                    ),
                    #style="margin-top: 20px;",
                    gap="20px",
                ),
                ui.layout_columns(
                    ui.card(
                        ui.card_header("Career Stage"),
                        ui.output_plot("plot_career"),
                        ),
                    ui.card(
                        ui.card_header("Institution"),
                        ui.output_plot("plot_institution"),
                    ),
                    #style="margin-top: 20px;",
                    gap="20px",
                ),
                ui.card(
                    ui.output_plot("plot_legend"),
                    height="100px"
                    ),
                #ui.layout_columns(  # deprecated
                #    ui.card(ui.output_data_frame("show_data")),
                #    style="margin-top: 20px;",
                #),
            )
        )
    )
    


@module.server
def server_participants(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session, data: pd.DataFrame, data_meta:dict):

    @reactive.Calc()
    def filtered_data() -> pd.DataFrame:
        data_out = data
        if input.gender() != "all":
            data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Gender"] == input.gender()]
        if input.age() != "all":
            data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Age"] == input.age()]
        if input.organisation() != "all":
            data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Organisation"] == input.organisation()]
        if input.career_stage() != "all":
            data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Career Stage"] == input.career_stage()]
        if input.country() != "all":
            data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Country"] == input.country()]
        return data_out  


    @render.data_frame
    def show_data():
        return filtered_data()


    @render.text
    def show_n():
        return f"N={len(filtered_data())} of {data_meta['N_used']}"

    
    @render.plot
    def plot_legend():
        field = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby()
        keys = list(filtered_data()[field].cat.categories) if field else ['All data']
        #keys = ["Male","Female","Non-binary / third Gender","Prefer to self-describe", "Prefer not to say"]

        f,ax = plt.subplots()
        pal = color_palette()
        handles,labels = [],[]
        for i,k in enumerate(keys):
            handles.append(plt.Rectangle((0, 0), 0, 0, facecolor=0.5 + 0.5 * array(to_rgb(pal[i])), edgecolor='black'))
            labels.append(k)
        ax.legend(
            handles=handles, labels=labels,
            #title=field, 
            handlelength=4)
        move_legend(
            ax, "center",
            #bbox_to_anchor=(.5, 1), 
            ncol=3, frameon=False,
            #title=field
        )
        plt.axis('off')
        ax.set_aspect(.1)
        f.tight_layout()
            

    @render.plot
    def plot_age():
        if len(filtered_data()) < 3:
            plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot",
                     horizontalalignment='center',
                     verticalalignment='center')
            plt.axis('off')
        else:
            field = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby()
            order = ['18-24','25-34','35-44','45-54','55-64','65-74','75 or older','Prefer not to say']
            x_tick_labels = ['18-24','25-34','35-44','45-54','55-64','65-74','75\nor older','Prefer\nnot to say']
            
            plot_kwargs=dict(kde_kws=dict(bw_adjust=1.3, cut=0), legend=False)
            if input.metric()=='Density':
                plot_kwargs = {**plot_kwargs,**dict(stat="density", common_norm=False)}
            
            try:         
                #f = sns.catplot(x='Age', data=data, order=order, kind='count', hue='Gender', aspect=1.5)
                f = histplot(x='Age', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=True,**plot_kwargs)
            except LinAlgError:
                f = histplot(x='Age', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=False, **plot_kwargs)
            f.set_xticks(ticks=order, labels=x_tick_labels, rotation=50)
            f.set_xlabel('')


    @render.plot
    def plot_gender():
        if len(filtered_data()) < 3:
            plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot",
                     horizontalalignment='center',
                     verticalalignment='center')
            plt.axis('off')
        else:
            field = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby()
            order = ["Male","Female","Non-binary / third Gender","Prefer to self-describe", "Prefer not to say"]
            x_tick_labels = ["Male","Female","Non-binary\n/ third Gender","Prefer to\nself-describe", "Prefer\nnot to say"]
            
            plot_kwargs=dict(kde_kws=dict(bw_adjust=1.3, cut=0), legend=False)
            if input.metric()=='Density':
                plot_kwargs = {**plot_kwargs,**dict(stat="density", common_norm=False)}
            
            try:         
                #f = sns.catplot(x='Age', data=data, order=order, kind='count', hue='Gender', aspect=1.5)
                f = histplot(x='Gender', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=True, **plot_kwargs)
            except LinAlgError:
                f = histplot(x='Gender', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=False, **plot_kwargs)
            f.set_xticks(ticks=order, labels=x_tick_labels, rotation=50)
            f.set_xlabel('')
     

    @render.plot
    def plot_career():
        if len(filtered_data()) < 3:
            plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot",
                     horizontalalignment='center',
                     verticalalignment='center')
            plt.axis('off')
        else:
            field = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby()
            order = [
                'Ph.D. student', 'Completed PhD',
                'Postdoctoral Researcher or Staff Scientist', 
                'Assistant Professor or equivalent', 
                'Associate Professor or equivalent', 
                'Full Professor', 
                'Other', 
                'Prefer not to say']
            x_tick_labels = [
                'PhD\nStudent', 'PhD\nCompleted', 
                'Postdoc\nor Staff', 
                'Assistant\nProfessor', 
                'Associate\nProfessor', 
                'Full\nProfessor', 
                'Other', 
                'Prefer\nnot to say']
            
            plot_kwargs=dict(kde_kws=dict(bw_adjust=1, cut=0), legend=False)
            if input.metric()=='Density':
                plot_kwargs = {**plot_kwargs,**dict(stat="density", common_norm=False)}
            
            #f = sns.catplot(x='Career Stage', data=data, order=order, kind='count', hue='Gender', aspect=1.5)
            try:         
                f = histplot(x='Career Stage', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=True, **plot_kwargs)
            except LinAlgError:
                f = histplot(x='Career Stage', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=False, **plot_kwargs)
            f.set_xticks(order, x_tick_labels,rotation=50)
            f.set_xlabel('')
    

    @render.plot
    def plot_institution():
        if len(filtered_data()) < 3:
            plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot",
                     horizontalalignment='center',
                     verticalalignment='center')
            plt.axis('off')
        else:
            field = None if (input.groupby() == 'No grouping') else input.groupby()
            order = ['University','Independent Research Institute','Healthcare Organisation','Government Agency','Commercial Entity','Other', 'Prefer not to say']
            x_tick_labels = ['University','Independent\nResearch\nInstitute','Healthcare\nOrganisation','Government\nAgency','Commercial\nEntity','Other', 'Prefer\nnot to say']

            plot_kwargs=dict(kde_kws=dict(bw_adjust=1., cut=0), legend=False)
            if input.metric()=='Density':
                plot_kwargs = {**plot_kwargs,**dict(stat="density", common_norm=False)}
            
            try:         
                f = histplot(x='Organisation', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=True, **plot_kwargs)
            except LinAlgError:
                f = histplot(x='Organisation', data=filtered_data(), hue=field, kde=False, **plot_kwargs)
            f.set_xticks(order, x_tick_labels,rotation=50)
            f.set_xlabel('')

name: module_predictions.py

""" EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App published on https://eeg100.org written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk) in 2024 using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment """ import pandas as pd from pathlib import Path from shiny import Inputs, Outputs, Session, module, render, ui, reactive import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from seaborn import kdeplot, cubehelix_palette, set_theme #@reactive.Calc() def selection_sidebar(data): return ui.sidebar( ui.card( ui.card_header("Subset Data"), ui.input_select( "gender", "Gender", choices=['all']+list(data['Gender'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "age", "Age Group", choices=['all']+list(data['Age'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "career_stage", "Career Stage", choices=['all']+list(data['Career Stage'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "organisation", "Type of Organisation", choices=['all']+list(data['Organisation'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "country", "Country", choices=['all']+sorted(data['Country'].unique()), ), #ui.input_select( # "worked_with", # "Worked with EEG", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['Worked with EEG'].unique()), #), #ui.input_select( # "n_papers", # "Number of EEG Papers", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['EEG Papers'].unique()), #), ui.output_text_verbatim("show_n",placeholder=True), ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Sort by"), ui.input_select( "metric", "", choices=['Mean', 'Median'], ), ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Display format"), ui.input_select( "aspect", "", choices=['Wide','Slim'], ), ), width="300px", ) @module.ui def ui_prediction(data:pd.DataFrame): return ui.nav_panel( "Future: Predictions", ui.page_fluid( ui.layout_sidebar( selection_sidebar(data), ui.card( ui.card_header("Predicting the future"), ui.output_plot("plot_prediction"), height="1600px", #full_screen=True ), ui.output_ui("text_prediction"), ui.card( ui.card_header("Innovations in next 10 Years"), ui.output_ui("text_10years"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Innovations in next 100 Years"), ui.output_ui("text_100years"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ) ) ) @module.server def server_prediction(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session, data: pd.DataFrame, data_desc:dict, data_meta:dict,data_text: pd.DataFrame): @reactive.Calc() def filtered_data() -> pd.DataFrame: data_out = data if input.gender() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Gender"] == input.gender()] if input.age() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Age"] == input.age()] if input.organisation() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Organisation"] == input.organisation()] if input.career_stage() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Career Stage"] == input.career_stage()] if input.country() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Country"] == input.country()] return data_out @render.text def show_n(): return f"N={len(filtered_data())} of {data_meta['N_used']}" cwd = Path(__file__).parent predictions_xshort = pd.read_csv(cwd / "data/ShortenedTitles.csv", header=None, delimiter=";")#.to_dict() def _textresp(field): desc = data_desc[field]#.upper() desc = "?
".join(desc.split("? ")) # d = list(data_text[field].sample(frac=1)) resp = [] for res in d: if isinstance(res,str): resp.append(res.strip()) #print(res) resp = [r for r in resp if r!=""] # count = ( "
====================" f"
{len(resp)} answers" "
====================" ) return "

".join([desc+count]+resp) def _plot(fig=False, txt=False): if len(filtered_data()) < 3: plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot", horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='center') plt.axis('off') else: # prepare data - short Qs field = 'Predictions_' field_desc = 'Q_full' # 'Q_full' ks = ['ResponseId'] + [k for k in filtered_data().keys() if (field in k)] data_Q_imp = filtered_data()[ks] data_Q_imp = pd.wide_to_long(data_Q_imp, field, 'ResponseId',"Q").reset_index() data_Q_imp[field] = data_Q_imp[field].astype(float) if input.aspect() == "Wide": ks_dict = {predictions_xshort[1][i]:predictions_xshort[0][i] for i in range(len(predictions_xshort))} else: ks_dict = {k:str(data_desc[k]) for k in ks[1:]} data_Q_imp['Q_full'] = data_Q_imp['Q'].apply(lambda x: ks_dict[field+str(x)].split(' - ')[-1]) data_Q_imp['answered'] = data_Q_imp['Predictions_'].notna() coltitles = [data_desc[k] for k in ks[1::]] coltitles = [v.split(' - ')[-1] for v in coltitles] # define order of e´questions if input.metric() == 'Median': data_ordered = data_Q_imp[[field_desc, field]].groupby(field_desc).median().sort_values(field, ascending=False).reset_index() else: data_ordered = data_Q_imp[[field_desc, field]].groupby(field_desc).mean().sort_values(field, ascending=False).reset_index() # text if txt: s = [] for i, cur_desc in enumerate(data_ordered[field_desc]): d_tmp = data_Q_imp[data_Q_imp[field_desc]==cur_desc] metric = d_tmp[field].median() if input.metric() == "Median" else d_tmp[field].mean() s.append(f"{i+1} - {metric:.1f} years, std:{d_tmp[field].std():.2f} - {sum(d_tmp['answered'] == True)/len(d_tmp)*100:.1f}% answered - {cur_desc}") return "

".join(s) # figure if fig: set_theme(style="white", rc={"axes.facecolor": (0, 0, 0, 0)}) # color palette n_plots = 36 pal = cubehelix_palette(n_plots, rot=-.25, light=.7) # Initialize the figure object f = plt.figure(figsize=(10,15)) axes_kde = [ plt.subplot2grid((n_plots, 4), (i, 0), colspan=3) for i in range(n_plots) ] axes_never = [ plt.subplot2grid((n_plots, 4), (i, 3), colspan=1) for i in range(n_plots) ] # plot loop #predictions = [] for i, cur_desc in enumerate(data_ordered[field_desc]): #cur_desc = order[i] d_tmp = data_Q_imp[data_Q_imp[field_desc]==cur_desc] kdeplot(x=field,data=d_tmp, bw_adjust=.5, clip_on=False, fill=True, alpha=1, linewidth=1.5, cut=0, warn_singular=False, ax=axes_kde[i], color=pal[i]) if input.metric() == "Median": axes_kde[i].axvline(d_tmp[field].median(), color='r',linestyle='-') else: axes_kde[i].axvline(d_tmp[field].mean(), color='r',linestyle='-') #predictions.append(d_tmp[field].median()) axes_kde[i].spines['left'].set_visible(True) axes_kde[i].spines['top'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].spines['right'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].spines['bottom'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].set_xlim([0,120]) if i != n_plots-1: axes_kde[i].set_xlabel('') axes_kde[i].set_xticks([]) axes_kde[i].set_xticklabels([]) else: axes_kde[i].set_xlabel('Prediction (in Years)') axes_kde[i].set_ylim([0,.06]) axes_kde[i].set_yticks([]) axes_kde[i].set_yticklabels([]) if input.aspect() == 'Wide': axes_kde[i].set_ylabel(cur_desc, rotation=0., horizontalalignment='right') else: axes_kde[i].set_ylabel(i+1) axes_kde[i].set_title('') # percentage never n_total = len(d_tmp) offset = 0. for boolean in [True, False]: count = sum(d_tmp['answered']==boolean) perc = count/n_total*100 color = pal[i] if boolean else 'r' axes_never[i].barh(0.03, perc, height=.06,label=boolean, left=offset, color=color) offset += perc #axes_never[i].axis('off') axes_never[i].spines['left'].set_visible(False) axes_never[i].spines['top'].set_visible(False) axes_never[i].spines['right'].set_visible(False) axes_never[i].spines['bottom'].set_visible(False) axes_never[i].set_xlim([0,100]) if i != n_plots-1: axes_never[i].set_xlabel('') axes_never[i].set_xticks([]) axes_never[i].set_xticklabels([]) else: axes_never[i].set_xlabel('reply rate (in %)') axes_never[i].set_ylabel('') axes_never[i].set_ylim([0,.06]) axes_never[i].set_yticks([]) axes_never[i].set_yticklabels([]) axes_never[i].set_title('') f.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.0) @render.plot def plot_prediction(): _plot(fig=True) @render.text def text_prediction(): if input.aspect() == "Slim": return _plot(txt=True) @render.text def text_10years(): return _textresp('Innovations 10 yrs_TEXT') @render.text def text_100years(): return _textresp('Innovations 100 yrs_TEXT')

name: module_priorities.py
content:
""" EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App published on https://eeg100.org written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk) in 2024 using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment """ import pandas as pd from shiny import Inputs, Outputs, Session, module, render, ui, reactive import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from seaborn import countplot, cubehelix_palette #@reactive.Calc() def selection_sidebar(data): return ui.sidebar( ui.card( ui.card_header("Subset Data"), ui.input_select( "gender", "Gender", choices=['all']+list(data['Gender'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "age", "Age Group", choices=['all']+list(data['Age'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "career_stage", "Career Stage", choices=['all']+list(data['Career Stage'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "organisation", "Type of Organisation", choices=['all']+list(data['Organisation'].cat.categories), ), ui.input_select( "country", "Country", choices=['all']+sorted(data['Country'].unique()), ), #ui.input_select( # "worked_with", # "Worked with EEG", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['Worked with EEG'].unique()), #), #ui.input_select( # "n_papers", # "Number of EEG Papers", # choices=['all']+sorted(data['EEG Papers'].unique()), #), ui.output_text_verbatim("show_n",placeholder=True), ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Display format"), ui.input_select( "aspect", "", choices=['Wide','Slim'], ), ), #ui.card( # ui.card_header("Sort by"), # ui.input_select( # "metric", # "", # choices=['Mean', 'Median'], # ), #), width="300px", ) @module.ui def ui_priority(data:pd.DataFrame): return ui.nav_panel( "Future: Priorities", ui.page_fluid( ui.layout_sidebar( selection_sidebar(data), ui.card( ui.card_header("Priorities of the Experts"), ui.output_plot("plot_priority"), height="1200px", #full_screen=True ), ui.output_ui("text_priority"), ui.card( ui.card_header("Biggest barriers for EEG"), ui.output_ui("text_barriers"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ui.card( ui.card_header("Most promising current developments"), ui.output_ui("text_promise"), height="600px", #full_screen=True ), ) ) ) @module.server def server_priority(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session, data: pd.DataFrame, data_desc:dict, data_meta:dict, data_text: pd.DataFrame): @reactive.Calc() def filtered_data() -> pd.DataFrame: data_out = data if input.gender() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Gender"] == input.gender()] if input.age() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Age"] == input.age()] if input.organisation() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Organisation"] == input.organisation()] if input.career_stage() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Career Stage"] == input.career_stage()] if input.country() != "all": data_out = data_out.loc[data_out["Country"] == input.country()] return data_out @render.text def show_n(): return f"N={len(filtered_data())} of {data_meta['N_used']}" def _textresp(field): desc = data_desc[field]#.upper() desc = "?
".join(desc.split("? ")) # d = list(data_text[field].sample(frac=1)) resp = [] for res in d: if isinstance(res,str): resp.append(res.strip()) #print(res) resp = [r for r in resp if r!=""] # count = ( "
====================" f"
{len(resp)} answers" "
====================" ) return "

".join([desc+count]+resp) def _plot(fig=False, txt=False): if len(filtered_data()) < 3: plt.text(.5,.5,"not enouth data\nto plot", horizontalalignment='center', verticalalignment='center') plt.axis('off') else: # last question - importance of specific developments for work field = 'Importance to work_' ks = ['ResponseId']+[k for k in data.keys() if field in k] data_Q_imp = filtered_data()[ks] data_Q_imp = pd.wide_to_long(data_Q_imp, 'Importance to work_', 'ResponseId',"Q") order_resp = ['Not at all','Slightly','Moderately','Very','Extremely'] x_dict = {order_resp[i]:i for i in range(len(order_resp))} coltitles = [data_desc[k] for k in ks[1::]] coltitles = [v.split(' - ')[-1] for v in coltitles] # dont change data_Q_imp[field] = pd.Categorical( data_Q_imp[field], categories=order_resp, ordered=True)#.fillna(order[-1]) field2=field+'int' data_Q_imp[field2] = data_Q_imp[field].factorize(sort=True)[0] # define order of e´questions data_ordered = data_Q_imp.reset_index()[['Q', field2]].groupby('Q').mean().sort_values(field2, ascending=False).reset_index() # text if txt: d = [f"{i+1} - {coltitles[Q-1]}" for i, Q in enumerate(data_ordered['Q'])] return "

".join(d) # figure if fig: n_plots = 19 # color palette pal = cubehelix_palette(n_plots, rot=-.25, light=.7) # Initialize the figure object #f = plt.figure(figsize=(5,8)) f = plt.figure(figsize=(5,15)) axes_kde = [ plt.subplot2grid((n_plots, 3), (i, 0), colspan=3) for i in range(n_plots) ] # plot loop for i, Q in enumerate(data_ordered['Q']): d_tmp = data_Q_imp.reset_index()[data_Q_imp.reset_index()['Q']==Q] countplot(x=field,data=d_tmp, #bw_adjust=.5, clip_on=False, stat='percent', width=1., fill=True, alpha=1, linewidth=1.5, ax=axes_kde[i], color=pal[i]) axes_kde[i].axvline(pd.to_numeric(d_tmp[field].apply(lambda x: x_dict[x])).mean(), color='r',linestyle='-') axes_kde[i].spines['left'].set_visible(True) axes_kde[i].spines['top'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].spines['right'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].spines['bottom'].set_visible(False) axes_kde[i].set_ylim([0,60]) if i != n_plots-1: axes_kde[i].set_xlabel('') axes_kde[i].set_xticks([]) axes_kde[i].set_xticklabels([]) else: axes_kde[i].set_xlabel('Rated Importance') #axes_kde[i].set_ylim([0,.06]) axes_kde[i].set_yticks([]) axes_kde[i].set_yticklabels([]) if input.aspect() == 'Wide': axes_kde[i].set_ylabel(coltitles[Q-1].split(' (')[0], rotation=0., horizontalalignment='right')#, fontweight="bold") else: axes_kde[i].set_ylabel(i+1) axes_kde[i].set_title('') #plt.show() f.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.0) return f @render.plot def plot_priority(): _plot(fig=True) @render.text def text_priority(): if input.aspect() == "Slim": return _plot(txt=True) @render.text def text_barriers(): return _textresp('Biggest barriers_TEXT') @render.text def text_promise(): return _textresp('Promising current_TEXT')

name: module_startpage.py
content:
""" EEG100 Community Survey Shiny App published on https://eeg100.org written by Dominik Welke (d.welke@leeds.ac.uk) in 2024 using shiny-python for the app and shinylive for deployment """ import pandas as pd from shiny import Inputs, Outputs, Session, module, render, ui from shinywidgets import output_widget, register_widget from plotly.express import choropleth, colors @module.ui def ui_map(): return ui.nav_panel( "About", ui.page_fluid( output_widget("map"), ui.output_ui("disclaimer"), #ui.tags.br(), ui.output_ui("intro_blob"), ui.output_ui("redirect"), ) ) @module.server def server_map(input: Inputs, output: Outputs, session: Session, data_country: pd.DataFrame, data_meta, data): map = choropleth( data_country, locations="Countrycode", color="N", hover_name="Country", # column to add to hover information color_continuous_scale=colors.sequential.Blugrn) map.update_geos( projection_type="natural earth", # mercator,robinson,winkel3, homolosine, stereographic, natural earth showcountries = True) map.update_layout( autosize=True, margin = dict( l=0, r=0, b=0, t=0, pad=4, autoexpand=True ), # width=800, # height=400, ) register_widget("map", map) @render.text def disclaimer(): return ( "* The worldmap implemented in the visualization package " "does not accurately handle disputed or occupied territory. " "This does not reflect the view of the authors" ", and we are trying to find a better solution." "

") @render.text def intro_blob(): participant_str = ( "EEG100 Community Survey" "
" "In late 2023 we asked experts in the field of Electroencephalography to answer a survey on the past and future premises of EEG. " f"We received {data_meta['N_used']} complete sets of responses (among {data_meta['N_all']} total submissions; " f"completion rate: {data_meta['N_used']/data_meta['N_all']*100:.1f}%). " # high drop out f"While we cannot rule out that individual participants contributed multiple responses, " f"we will assume that these complete datasets come from {data_meta['N_used']} participants. " f"These paricipants together have an impressive {int(data['EEG Experience'].sum())} years of total EEG experience " f"(mean={data['EEG Experience'].mean():.1f} years, std={data['EEG Experience'].std():.1f} years) " f"with {len(data.loc[data['EEG Papers']=='More than 50 publications'])} of our respondents having " "more than 50 academic publications using EEG. " f"We have participants from {len(data['Country'].unique())-1} countries across the whole world, though unfortunately with " "a strong overrepresentation of european and northern american countries. " "We also obsere a strong gender imbalance, in all career stages above PhD level; unfortunately these biases are likely to be representatitve for the field. " "

" ) gui_str = ( "We created this shiny-app for you to explore the data on your own - " "our participants shared a wealth of information and opinions with us and it will be hard to do this justice in a short opinion piece! " "Please note, that the free text responses can not be filtered by participant groups to avoid deanonymisation. " 'If there is a particular analysis you think is missing feel free to reach out to us, or simply download the data and go for it!' ) return "".join((participant_str,gui_str)) @render.text def redirect(): return '
Close the survey app and go back to startpage'

name: data/readme.md
content:
`resp_data.tsv` - demographic information and numerical responses by the participant

`text_data.tsv` - all free-text responses of the participants (shuffled, to ensure anonymity)

`desc_data.json` - dictionary with the full questions as displayed in the survey

`meta_data.json` - number of response datasets pre and post removing unfinished entries

						The major breakthrough in the use of EEG for fundamental brain research is the discovery of the neurophysiological oscillatory mechanisms regulating brain rhythms in the wake-sleep cycle and the processing of information during cognitive and affective demands. The major breakthrough in using EEG for clinical brain research is using EEG biomarkers for the diagnosis, prognosis, disease monitoring, and therapy response in patients with Epilepsy, Encephalopathies, Coma/Vegetative states, and in the control of anesthesia. 					MEG	At the end of the first 100 years of EEG, advanced recording techniques, including MEG, high density EEG, and stereo EEG, are guiding the surgical treatment of epilepsy, often leading to seizure free. As EEG technology progresses, new clinical applications are beginning to open up. Soon we will have clinical diagnostics for developmental and cognitive dysfunctions that can be used to evaluate and guide treatment options. In addition, brain computer interfaces have the potential to restore freedom and mobility to people with disabilities.		The door between human neuroscience research and the clinical world is very small. Getting clinical data out to researchers and getting new techniques and software into the clinic is very challenging. Ethics and regulatory issues are a big part of this, but other issues include incentives. For example, the incentive of the clinician is to diagnose and treat individual patients and bill for those activities; not to curate data and manage records for research purposes. Similarly the incentives for academic researchers is to get short-term grants quickly and low hanging fruit publications; both of which are easier to accomplish if the researcher has full control over the data.	As of today, advance computer programming is a unique and powerful skill that is rare in neurosciences and practically non-existent in the clinical world. Tools that help programming-illiterate individuals to code will open up opportunities, especially within hospitals. This will help integrate advanced analyzes into clinical care which will provide the evidence needed for new billing codes. This will have a huge impact on the clinical value of EEG.	As EEG technology progresses, new clinical applications are beginning to open up. Soon we will have clinical diagnostics for developmental and cognitive dysfunctions that can be used to evaluate and guide treatment options. In addition, brain computer interfaces have the potential to restore freedom and mobility to people with disabilities.	In the distant future, there is a possibility that EEG technology is a benefit to healthy individuals as well as patients. Methods for humans to interface with devices could allow improvements in communication with other humans as well as machines and databases. But I'll probably be dead before then.	In the future, pure visual assessment of standard density EEG will no longer be necessary. Instead, more advanced recording and signal processing methods will be combined to give a more information-rich picture of the underlying brain activity.

						The major breakthroughs have been: 1. Identification of the functionally-specific frequency bands  2. Identification of the epileptic waveforms 3. Use of clinical signature for varieties of stroke and neurodegeneration 4. Use of frequency bands and REM activity to identify the stages of the sleep cycle 5. ERP techniques to identify the involvement of numerous varieties of cognitive processing 6. The sweep VEP technique for measuring infant visual acuity in developmental disorders 7. Improved source localization through combination with MRI		The biggest barrier is the failure to make a concerted effort to provide detailed source localization of the scalp signals. A key requirement is an accurate model of the impedences of the various tissues in the path from the cortex to the scalp and the full 3D spatial layout of these tissues. A 3-spherical-shell model is totally inadequate for this purpose.  What is needed is extensive local intracortical stimulation and recording experiments to pin down the precise parameters of all tissues through a detailed forward model framework. Current approaches such as minimum norm inverse models are totally inadequate for this purpose.	1. The above comments lay out a strategy that could improve source localization by an order of magnitude, which would markedly increase the utility of EEG. 2. This should be done in conjunction with combined EEG/MEG measures giving the complete 3-vector information for full source localization. 3. Whole-head dry electrodes combined with machine learning analysis has the promise of identifying meaningful patterns relative to the varieties of cognitive function. The key here is to have a detailed scoring of the sequence of events in complex stimuli such as movies. 4. The resonant structure of early visual processing reflecting a variety of microcircuits remains almost totally unexplored, but could lead to major advances in the neruoscientific understanding of the human brain. 						The use of computers to be able to summarize and transform the data in many ways. This allowed researchers to extract information from the EEG that would otherwise remain invisible.  The development of BCI and mobile EEG together are creating a new way of interaction and communication with the world transcending existing physical limitations. 		In research, the biggest risk I perceive of using EEG is that it offers a virtually limitless well of information. There can be a sort of hypnotic effect of this on researchers, who feel everything needs to be linked to some feature of the EEG. This does not necessarily advance our knowledge, but is very effective in spending funds.  In cognitive neuroscience I also see a lot of people testing whether this or that component is "altered" in some disorder. In clinical practice, where time-pressure is a real thing, and the mental model of psychological difficulties is often biased towards "disorders", I see a risk of doing a quick EEG will replace a good conversation that might be much more helpful for the patient.  In commercial applications and their marketing, the limitations of EEG are often glossed over and unrealistic promises are made. Here I see the risk of personal EEG devices being sold, then people understand eventually its all BS and EEG will be discredited in general.	In first instance, I think the LLM's might have most impact by seriously accelerating the time it takes researchers to analyze their data. This could lead to an even greater volume of publications flooding our desks. If we are successful in solving that problem it might dramatically increase the quality of research being done.  I think the further development of BCI and mobile EEG together might be most promising. As EEG equipment becomes smaller and lighter, it can become more and more seamlessly integrated into daily life.   The development of AI is likely to give a turbo boost in the range and flexibility of interaction between the wearer and the wearable.			Any wearable tech that has good spatial resolution and also the temporal resolution and low cost of EEG will replace EEG in the future.

						Combining EEG with real-time statistical machine learning techniques has given birth to the very exciting field of non-invasive Brain Computer Interfaces (BCI). Whilst EEG continues to underpin most non-invasive BCI research, we are seeing it combined with other hybrid modalities (fNIRS, EMG etc.) and the complementary fields of robotics and shared control, which is enabling Brain Machine Interfaces to be evaluated and even used outside the laboratory setting. Consequently we are seeing clinical application of these closed-loop EEG-based systems in neurorehabilitation and some assistive technologies.		In commercial settings there is a risk that EEG is beginning to be seen as plug-and-play, yet in reality a lot of skill is still required to mount and calibrate the electrodes to ensure good signal quality. Most BCIs require substantial training time and support from expert researchers. Therefore, there is a risk to the BCI community that early commercialisation of such technology could be mis-sold to / misinterpreted by the public, which could harm future investment and trust. It could be argued that a similar fate was bestowed upon the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI), as it followed a rollercoaster of success and setbacks, before making the recent significant leaps forward in generative AI.	There are 3 current developments that will lead to major breakthroughs towards daily usage of Brain Computer Interfaces: (1) Improvements to the hardware itself: moving away from the functional elements and considering more ergonomics and human factors. We are already seeing more comfortable, aesthetically pleasing, wireless, dry-electrode systems, but currently they often come at a cost in terms of reduced signal quality. (2) Hybrid systems that combine complementary modalities (e.g. fNIRS) to yield a more robust system. (3) Shared control systems, which enable the user's EEG to be interpreted in the context in which the BCI is operating (akin to driving assistance, or predictive text), will improve decoding accuracy, robustness and reduce user workload.			For some patients, who may elect to be long-term BCI users, an invasive approach may well yield better signals, supporting higher information transfer rates and better accuracies, supporting them to perform a range of activities of daily living. Nevertheless there are obvious costs and risks associated with surgery. Therefore, I believe there will always be a role for EEG in Brain Computer Interfaces for the majority of users who will simply not wish to elect for surgery.

						George H. W. Bush authorized the Human Brain Project in 1990 and authorized over 2 billion dollars for the first decade.  I was a NIH project leader at the time and helped to evaluate and fund a variety of quantitative EEG (QEEG) and MEG grants.  I was also responsible for the development of the first 128 channel EEG system to aid in inverse EEG source solutions.  Brain networks were evaluated using PET, SPECT, QEEG and MEG and the 1909 Brodmann areas were evaluated and confirmed.   Brain network software was developed, e.g., EEG/MEG coherence and phase differences and information flow, etc. to further confirm the existence of Brodmann areas that corresponded to unique cytoarchitectures in each area.  The 2nd decade of the Human Brain Project involved a 2nd approximate 2 billion dollars in funding to further evaluate brain networks and to combine different imaging methods.   This science helped further develop quantitative EEG which has resulted over 160,000 QEEG peer reviewed publications cited in the National Library of Medicine database (e.g., Pubmed).		QEEG was first used by Hans Berger in 1934 and used to measures scalp recorded electricity for nearly 100 years with no reports of injury.    Today high school and college students routinely measure their EEG at home and school with no harm.  This is because today’s inexpensive EEG amplifiers have protections to prevent any reverse direction of electricity to a person’s scalp and the standards are specified by the FDA since the 1980s.  The biggest risk is false information about possible harm to measuring the EEG and then using invalid digital methods to distort replace a patient’sEEG without their knowledge nor consent.  The greatest risk is distortion of a patient’s digital EEG data using Independent Components Analysis (ICA) to then allegedly remove artifact using ICA replacement (ICA) of the patient’s original EEG by using a smaller number of ICA components to recreate a different and distorted time series without the patient’s knowledge or permission. 			Social Neuroscience 			EEG, has seen numerous breakthroughs over the past century, greatly influencing our understanding of brain function and offering valuable applications in various fields. Some of the most significant developments include: Alpha and Beta Rhythms, Epileptic Diagnostics, Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs), Neurofeedback and Cognitive Training, Real-time Functional Mapping. So the last 100 years of EEG research and application have been transformative. The technique has been a cornerstone in the neuroscientific field, helping us understand the brain's complex dynamics and offering tools and technologies that bring tangible benefits to society.		Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), Spatial Resolution Limitations, Clinical Interpretation, Standardization-Different labs or clinics might use varying methodologies, electrode placements, or analysis techniques. This lack of standardization can lead to inconsistent results, making it challenging to compare or integrate findings across studies or institutions.Commercial Overreach.	Wearable and Wireless EEG, Machine Learning and AI Integration, Advanced Source Localization Techniques, hybrid system, Closed-loop Systems, expended neurofeedback applications.Brain-computer interfaces are seeing applications in gaming, virtual reality, and even as assistive technologies. As the technology becomes more streamlined and affordable, BCIs could become as ubiquitous as smartphones, allowing direct brain interaction with digital platforms.	Miniaturization and Enhanced Portability, Improved Signal Processing, AI-driven Real-time Analysis, Enhanced Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs), Comprehensive Integration with Other Technologies-Integration of EEG with other biometric tools, such as heart rate monitors or eye-tracking systems, could provide a holistic understanding of an individual's state, Affordable and High-resolution Devices.	Non-contact EEG, Full brain mapping, Seamless Brain-Computer Integration, Neuro-enhancement and Training-Advanced EEG-driven neurofeedback might allow individuals to "train" specific cognitive or emotional skills, optimizing brain function for specific tasks or states.This could redefine education, professional training, and mental health interventions, allowing for tailored cognitive enhancements.Predictive Brain Modeling, Global Neural Networks- Drawing a parallel to today's digital networks, future EEG tech might facilitate neural networks, where individuals can share, amalgamate, or even "stream" cognitive experiences.This could redefine social interactions, education, and collective decision-making. It would also raise profound questions about individuality, privacy, and societal structures. 						Clinical monitoring: EEG for identifying sub-clinical seizures, sleep disorders, and other pathologies has had a tremendous impact on clinical practice, the ways in which patients are treated and their levels of recovery and quality of life, and our understanding of the underlying mechanisms. The low cost and portability of EEG has made it valuable for many diverse patient groups.  Sleep staging: While there are behavioural correlates of sleep stages, a full understanding of the stages of sleep, their mechanisms, and their value for the awake organism wouldn't be possible without EEG. This feeds into understanding and helping those with sleep disorders, as well as understanding bigger philosophical questions about consciousness and wakefulness.  Cognitive neuroscience: For me, some of the best cognitive applications of EEG have been ERP studies in the 1990s of the various cognitive processes proposed by Tulving to underly episodic memory encoding and retrieval. They are I think clear examples of the benefit of EEG for testing predictions about whether two processes are dissociable, and in what temporal order they occur.		The same things that affect all of science currently: reproducibility and replicability. EEG is inexpensive and widely available, so it is straightforward to run an EEG study and find evidence of some clinical marker or something of commercial value, e.g., neuromarketing. The barrier is to ensure that studies are well-powered, grounded in theory, protected from QRPs, and conducted openly. Subdermal electrodes that can be worn without it hurting or giving concerns about infection would be invaluable in solving the signal quality issues. 				Brain-Computer Interfacing	MEG	I consider the adoption of EEG outside the neurological (clinical) context a major breakthrough. EEG was the first technique that allowed us to go beyond behavioral (reaction time) experiments and has shed light on the sequential and parallel nature of cortical processing (perception, decision making, action preparation and execution, and monitoring).		The biggest barrier to me is that neither the EEG signal nor the artifacts have changed over the years, but that naive researchers/people expect that new hardware makes the acquisition of EEG easier. Of course it is easier (cheaper, faster, more noise resilient) in some regards, but that still does not make it easy. Affordable consumer-grade EEG systems create expectations that are not met in reality. Related to this is that poor communication about how the brain and cognition works leads to expectations among people and non-neuroscience researchers that are similar to phrenology, i.e., how can we use EEG to simply assess attention, emotion, memory or other cognitive constructs without understanding the complexity of those constructs. Luckily somehow people never ask me how to assess IQ using EEG, but that would have been a question in the same domain - except I guess there people understand or (want to) accept that IQ is too complex to be measured with a device as a single number, whereas for other contents that belief still seems to exist. 						At the clinical level, EEG has become a main investigation technique used to diagnose, sometimes with high accuracy and reliability, a host of neurological or psychiatric disorders. In this context, a major breakthrough pertains to the diagnosis of epilepsy (but also sleep disorders) in neurology, I think, for which EEG provides the gold standard diagnostic method.    In research, in psychology and neuroscience, EEG has steadily grown up to become nowadays a main investigation technique used to explore the organization and implementation of a myriad of brain processes, spanning from sensory processing to decision making. In this context, a major breakthrough concerns the discovery and characterization of specific EEG oscillations (theta, alpha, beta, gamma) contributing to cognition and more generally information processing in the (human) brain.    		EEG, unlike other methods, can easily be used and does not have big barriers, I think. If asked to mention one however, I would say "the wires" (i.e. literally the ones connecting the EEG sensors to the amplifier). I would suspect that EEG wireless technology, which is still in its infancy, if I'm not mistaken, could yield new and significant breakthroughs in cognitive but also clinical neuroscience. Wireless means that other technological barriers will probably have to be overcome, related to electrodes/sensors, but also data handling and processing in a wireless environment. This way, the ecological validity of EEG could increase substantially. Accordingly, the ecological validity of EEG is still limited and I see this as a big barrier.     	EEG data sharing (e.g. #EEGmanylabs), but also the use of open-source software and applications are new developments that should lead to rapid changes and breakthroughs in the use of EEG. Combined with technological advancements (e.g. wireless EEG), BCI based on EEG might lead to new major scientific discoveries (about the brain), but also novel treatments or interventions based on this specific technology (BCI).   	EEG electrodes and sensors (including at the scalp level) will not only record EEG, but also be able to directly influence and alter it. Hence, EEG will be used for entrainment, learning and brain plasticity because it will be combined or (better) integrated with online "(neuro)stimulations" techniques (like what we now know and use with TMS or tDCS). In turn, people or even patients could wear devices that will use/record EEG, but will also be able to influence online this neurophysiological signal, with the goal to change and improve learning and behavior. If working successfully, a new range of applications meant to treat neurological or affective disorders could open and develop. A second innovation (in the long run) could be to better relate EEG (e.g. specific/new EEG correlates yet to be discovered) to neurotransmission or specific neurotransmitters (dopamine, serotonin). 						EEG has indeed come a long way since its inception in the 1920s by Hans Berger. Initially, it was somewhat rudimentary and required invasive methods, but it has evolved into a sophisticated, non-invasive technology extensively used in neuroscience and medicine. Significant advancements include the transition from analog to digital systems, the advent of wireless EEG for more accessible long-term monitoring, and the integration of AI for complex data analysis. Despite its limitations in spatial resolution and susceptibility to interference, EEG remains an indispensable tool for diagnosing and studying various neurological conditions. A notable challenge in EEG research is the standardization of the data cleaning process. Additionally, the replication rate of EEG studies, which remains largely unquantified, is crucial for validating the reliability and consistency of EEG findings. The integration of machine learning techniques with EEG data has allowed for more sophisticated analysis and interpretation. 						EEG has seen many significant breakthroughs over the past 100 years. Here are some of the major milestones and their impact:  Identification of different brain waves: Researchers in the 1930s identified different brain wave patterns, such as alpha, beta, delta, and theta waves, each associated with different states of consciousness. Implications: The identification of different brain waves provided insights into various states of consciousness and activity, including sleep, relaxation, and wakefulness.  Diagnosis of epilepsy: EEG has been used to detect abnormal electrical patterns in the brain associated with epilepsy. Impact: This non-invasive method revolutionized the diagnosis and study of epilepsy, leading to improved treatment and understanding of the disease.  Evoked potentials: In the 1950s, researchers developed the capability to measure the brain's responses to specific sensory stimuli. Impacts: This discovery allowed for detailed studies of sensory processing and the cognitive functions of the brain.  Brain-Computer Interfaces: Pioneering steps were taken to develop systems allowing direct communication between the brain and computers. Impact: BCI technology holds the promise of enabling people with paralysis or other motor disorders to communicate or control external devices using their thoughts.  Real-time neurofeedback: Patients and participants can now view their brain activity in real-time and learn to modulate it. Implications: This technique has been employed in therapies for ADHD, anxiety, and other conditions.  EEG in cognitive neuroscience: The integration of EEG with other imaging modalities, such as fMRI, offers insights into cognitive processes and networks. Implications: This combination enables a more comprehensive understanding of how different brain regions collaborate on various cognitive tasks.  Portable and wearable EEG: With the advent of miniaturized wireless EEG systems in the 2010s, recording brain activity outside the laboratory became feasible. Implications: This technological leap expanded the applications of EEG to areas like meditation, gaming, and other everyday activities. 																																				0

						The inverse solution and advances in computational neuroscience have revolutionized our field. While medical disciplines went chasing after the latest fads in imaging and abandoned EEG in research and clinical applications (except in epileptology and polysomnography), the use of EEG as a method of functional neuroimaging has flourished. Moreover, improvements in computerized spatial modeling and sensor noise reduction have harnessed the superior temporal resolution of EEG tomography and have further refined the spatial resolution of EEG such that we can reliably use EEG in clinical and research applications without the ridiculously exorbitant costs of fMRI/MRI/SPECT/PET. EEG has much greater facility and a near zero risk to harm to the subject as opposed to the risk to harm presented by other imaging technologies.		The biggest barrier is posed by the community of neurologist who insist that only a neurologist can read and interpret EEG and who also cast aspersions at those who use quantitative EEG, EEG databases, and the inverse solutions (sLORETA, eLORETA, swLORETA) for source localization. While we have gained broad acceptance in behavioral neuroscience, the medical community - aided and abetted by big pharma - has always been the biggest barrier to acceptance of EEG in clinical setting (like EEG biofeedback/neurofeedback). These methods do not get the same level of funding as others for these reasons and that needs to be addressed. 						In my view, the major impact of EEG on society in the past century has been its use in clinical neurology. I would also like to point out an "absence of breakthrough" in that clinical EEG is still read "by eye" and that quantitative methods only assist this old-fashioned technique, rather than replace it.  The other major breakthrough of EEG has been the development of cognitive neuroscience research using intracranial EEG. Its unrivalled spatial and temporal resolutions and signal-to-noise ratio enable true progress in understanding how the brain represents and produces speech signals. This is on the verge of leading to usable Brain-Computer Interfaces to restore speech in neurological patients.		Scalp EEG in research: risk of associating sensor-level findings with focal brain activity. Lack of understanding of how EEG signals are generated may lead to false statement (e.g. changes in ERP amplitude and "more" or "less" brain activation).  Scalp EEG in the clinics: failure to recognize that quantitative techniques (AI-based feature search and detection, or summarized presentation of long-term recordings) can significantly improve clinical performance. They lead to various use/applications such as seizure diagnosis, monitoring cognitive state (e.g., using P300, Error-related potential, brain-to-brain synchrony), mind-based controls (using SSVEP, motor imagery, and so on). Trade-off between signal quality and comfortableness is the biggest barriers. Although nowadays we have devices, such as dry electrodes, that are easier to setup, their signal quality and comfortableness are usually lower compared to traditional setup that generally no one would use outside of essential research or clinical uses.  Signal stability is another barrier. For example, the impedance is usually different every setup and may degrade over time. Even running the same protocol, one could observe different bias or distortions in signals, such as spectrum, over different setups. For post or offline analysis, it is maybe less an issue, but for real time analysis, it could lead to unreliable results due to signal inconsistency. As far as I know, there is easy and quick way to calibrate and compensate. 						(1) the use of EEG measures to diagnose sleep disorders, epilepsy, brain death, and to monitor states of alertness, aiding in personalized treatment strategies (2) the use of intracranial EEG to define the functional specialization of neurons, e.g. discovery of receptive fields of single neurons in the visual cortex by Hubel and Wiesel, revolutionizing our understanding of visual processing (3) the discovery of ERPs and their associations with cognitive and affective processing, providing valuable insights into how the brain responds to and processes various stimuli (4) the use of the EEG measures as variables reflecting individual differences (in norm and psychopathology), enhancing our understanding of neurodiversity (5) the use of EEG in clinical brain–computer interfaces which allow individuals with paralysis to control assistive devices, enhancing their quality of life  		(1) overly sophisticated analyses - it's essential to strike a balance between the sophistication of signal processing methods and their interpretability. Opting for more transparent and comprehensible analysis techniques, even if they are less complex, can often yield more accessible and practical outcomes, fostering a better understanding of EEG data and its implications for brain function and clinical applications  (2) limited reliability and accuracy of some EEG measures as diagnostic tools for individual assessments - e.g., while ERPs hold promise in understanding group-level differences associated with certain disorders like OCD, their reliability and accuracy as sole diagnostic tools for individual assessments is limited. Integration with other diagnostic measures and clinical assessments is still necessary to improve their utility in individual diagnosis within psychiatric contexts.  (3) lack of standardized protocols in EEG-based scientific research - the use of different analysis techniques can hinder reproducibility of findings. Establishing universal standards could improve reliability and comparability of results.  (4) gap between researchers and practitioners - practitioners utilizing EEG-based techniques like neurofeedback may not consistently follow standardized protocols established through scientific research. This lack of adherence to standardized procedures could compromise the effectiveness and reliability of interventions. One barrier to use is the cost associated with deploying EEG - if caps and recording was cheaper then a lot more people would be playing with EEG and there would be huge progress. And yet another is the need to implement source localization for so many studies - for example - the use of EEG as a biomarker doesn't necessitate source localization. Source localization tends to only make it harder to replicate any individual study (this is of course my own speculation - there's no study I know of that actually makes this case but given all the little knobs you can turn and buttons you can press when doing source localization, I wouldn't be surprised if this were true). 				Multidimensional space-time-frequency decomposition		- Quantitative EEG analysis. Neurometrics. The work of Roy John and colleagues started the era of analysis of EEG using computers, allowing for a large number of new methods being used to both characterize and model the EEG data. This brought a huge impact on clinical applications, child and newborn screening applications, etc. Cognitive Neuroscience grew as a major field when EEG responses could also be quantified in controlled experiments, e.g. Evoked potentials, PCA, ICA, artifact correction, electrophysiological source imaging.  - Neuronal mass models for explaining EEG dynamics. Despite some misleading attempts to claim a chaotic behavior of the EEG, the appearance of models that mimic the EEG dynamics, opened a big space for new insights on the possible physiological phenomena originating EEG. This also brought a large number of new ways of extract information from the EEG using time series analysis, chaos, and probabilistic methods. Less important regarding clinical applications. - EEG-fMRI conjoint recordings. This allowed to bring back the importance of the high temporal resolution when the MRI-based neuroimages started to gain large popularity. The complementarity of EEG and all other neuroimaging techniques, makes it to be considered as a valued data that contains relevant information about brain functioning. Multimodality has been later extended (e.g. EEG-MEG, EEG-fNIRS). - EEG-based Neurofeedback. I include here the BCI applications as part of neurofeedback as this is a natural mechanism for the brain to learn how to control any system once it has the proper information to evaluate/adjust the relationship between action and response. Despite clinical applications has not been completely successful, the finding that the brain can adjust itself using feedback of its activity or that EEG signals can be used for interacting with external technology, created a new point of view about the importance of the information contained in the EEG. - Hyperscanning EEG. Although still very young, there are enough evidence that suggest that the synchronization of EEG data among interacting subjects is not only real, but underlies many aspects of the human social behavior. This will probably be able to show that many of the high-level socio-psychological behavior (e.g. ability to learn in a classroom, empathy, engagement in psychotherapy, success in relationships or in working teams) might also be codified in the (hyperscanning) EEG signals, which therefore might be used to predict such behavior.  		- Research: a big barrier is the lack of a ground truth to relate the EEG signals with a more direct measurement of the “brain state”. For instance, if tMS or another technique allows to “impose” the source of a measured EEG, then this would be of major importance to test the source localization methods. - Clinical: The large variability across subjects for the current settings, still make it very slow to standardize applications and generalize the use of novel developments in EEG. 	- Measuring EEG during Magnetic or Electrical stimulation that can gives a ground truth about the sources. - Predicting epileptic seizures and other pathologies with enough time to treat the patient beforehand.  - Finding reliable neurofeedback applications that allow patients to train their brains in order to avoid psychological or psychiatric disorders. - Developing EEG-based AI to allow predict the diagnosis or prognosis of different pathologies such as cognitive decline, or learning disorders in children. 	- Neuromanagement and Neurotherapy. Using hyperscanning to create working teams that engage optimally with each other. EEG signals in an interaction protocol might help to decide who can be member of the same creative team or not. The same technology could be used by psychiatrics or psychoanalysts to evaluate the level of engagement of psychiatric patients with the treatment when this treatment is more based on psychological therapy. - Diagnosis of pathologies with EEG-based AI. Although 10 years is not much to create the huge databases needed to find the relevant patterns, there might be some AI applications to predict epileptic seizures, the level of sleep, the depth of anesthesia, learning disorders, autism, etc. 	- Neuromarketing. Creation of commercial content that is directed to each subject taking into account the individual inclination for a particular product or type of products according to the patterns contained in the EEG while using that product. - Neuroemotion. Creation of technology that evaluates the emotional state through EEG and can even be linked to a neural stimulator to intervene in pathological states.
